headline: Crispy Fried Chicken
description: Discover the technique for making deliciously crispy fried chicken with a crunchy coating on the outside and juicy, tender chicken inside.

video.description: See great technique for making crispy fried chicken.
video.name: Crispy Fried Chicken

name: Crispy Fried Chicken

recipeInstructions.text: Take your cut up chicken pieces and skin them if you prefer.

Put the flour in a large plastic bag (let the amount of chicken you are cooking dictate the amount of flour you use). Season the flour with paprika, salt and pepper to taste (paprika helps to brown the chicken).
Dip chicken pieces in buttermilk then, a few at a time, put them in the bag with the flour, seal the bag and shake to coat well.
Place the coated chicken on a cookie sheet or tray, and cover with a clean dish towel or waxed paper. LET SIT UNTIL THE FLOUR IS OF A PASTE-LIKE CONSISTENCY. THIS IS CRUCIAL!
Fill a large skillet (cast iron is best) about 1/3 to 1/2 full with vegetable oil. Heat until VERY hot.
Put in as many chicken pieces as the skillet can hold. Brown the chicken in HOT oil on both sides.
When browned, reduce heat and cover skillet; let cook for 30 minutes (the chicken will be cooked through but not crispy). Remove cover, raise heat again, and continue to fry until crispy.
Drain the fried chicken on paper towels. Depending on how much chicken you have, you may have to fry in a few shifts. Keep the finished chicken in a slightly warm oven while preparing the rest.

review.reviewBody: Used regular milk instead of buttermilk and it was still good. Everyone loved it.

I’m 68 and live in the country in the South and this is my first try at fried chicken. Go figure. Didn’t have buttermilk so I substituted evaporated milk. It turned out really good. I mean really good. (I’ve eaten lots of fried chicken, BBQ chicken, smoked chicken, and every other kind of chicken so I know good from bad.) Thank you for sharing your recipe. There are about 25 more chickens in the freezer that I just harvested and now they’re all waiting to plop in the pan.
Very mild on the spices. But flavorful. Used gluten free flour
Chicken coating was hard and chewy :(

It was crunchy but it was almost burned before it got to crunchy. I definitely overcooked it to get the crunch by then it was to hard to eat. It may be a good recipe but I'm not going to waste another chicken and dinner. If you are going to try it, be careful of the cooking time!

i would like to try this recipe, but i have a question. what is the trick to not having the outside burned by 350 oil? i tried to fry some chicken the other day in about an inch of oil, and it all burned on the outside, and was really undercooked inside. thanks in advance! /

This is the best fried chicken I've had in a long time. Recipe is just what the author said. I made no changes and it didn't take all that long to complete the task. It's even good cold. I'm going to keep this recipe as my go-to for really tasty fried chicken.
Turned out perfect!

I have made fried chicken before, first dredged in flour, then egg and finally flour. For whatever reason it comes out hard and dry. This recipe however, was simple with fewer steps and came out better. I love finding methods that work, and allow room for my own tastes and tweaks. Thank you for the method. It was a hit at dinner. 'Very crispy and super moist. The only change I made, was that I used coconut oil.

Mind you, although I am a great cook, I have never been able to fry chicken, which is astounding to me. This chicken was so overcooked. I cooked between a temp of 350 to 375 to start and then turned heat to low for the 30 minute cook. Then back up to finish the cooking like it says in the instructions. It was crispy! But tasted like nothing, as I’m sure the crust being overcooked just obliterated all the spices I put in the flour. The meat was SO tough and overcooked! This was bad! And a waste of time/oil... Fried chicken is definitely an art. You either have it or you don’t I guess.
It was a hit!!! My family loved it, there was no left overs.
Chicken Fingers

Great recipe for crispy chicken. I added some of my own seasonings to the flour and it was really crispy, moist and tasty. This will be my go to fried chicken recipe from now on. Almost forgot to mention it was really easy.
These wings were as good as a restaurant.I’ve made them a few times

Perfect! I've fried chicken a few times before and this is the best. I used an electric skillet and kept the temperature at 375 for browning and 200 for cooking it through. I didn't have buttermilk so I used 1 cup of milk and an egg instead. I used drumsticks with the skin on. The outside was nice and crispy and the meat was super moist.
I love this recipe! it is my first time making fried chicken. The tips helped me a lot. It turned out perfect. Thank you

I love allspice and use it all the time. I don’t think I’ve ever written a review to date. I thought my grandma made the best fried chicken, but I was wrong. I like my chicken crispy and this was crispy. The most tender fried chicken I’ve ever had. The only things I did different were to add some old bay seasoning and some garlic salt. I used an electric skillet and browned the chicken on high then reduced heat to 300 and fried for 24 minutes covered, turning the chicken half way through. Then I cranked it back on high to make crispy. I also placed on a cooling rack when done versus laying in paper towels. Awesome method for fabulous fried chicken!

Loved this recipe! Never made my own fried chicken but recently bought a BIG cast iron skillet. I used chicken drums and it turned out so crispy. 

I am going to experiment with the spices but the technique makes juicy and crispy fried chicken. Thanks!

First time I ever made fried chicken and I consider it a great success. I added more spices to the flour: more paprika, Mrs. Dash, cayenne pepper. And I soaked the chicken (all skinless thighs) in buttermilk for several hours rather than just dipping. I cooked it for about 15 minutes total, until it was the dark brown I like. Pretty good chicken for my first time!
This recipe worked out so wonderfully, I’ll continue to use it

I seasoned the oil first by adding garlic onion and green pepper for a couple minutes. 
Chicken turned out super crispy, the buttermilk made a BIG difference. highly recommend

Delicious... I soaked my chicken in the buttermilk for 2 hours before breading then and letting them rest. We made all drum sticks using a deep fryer. We fried them for 5 minutes and flipped them once. We started to check each drum stick at 2 minutes with a meat thermometer. Depending on the size of the drum stick it would take up to 5 minutes to reach 165 degrees all the way through. The chicken was tender and delicious.

I have never given a food review and I am terrible at frying chicken, but this was the best chicken I’ve ever had in my life and the recipe was simple. I made my own buttermilk mix and added a smidgen of thyme. This one is a keeper. Thank you.

This is a simple recipe but the technique is something I’ve never tried before. It works and it works really well. Time to let the chicken sit after coating may take a while and like the author said, this is crucial for best results. I marinated the chicken in buttermilk a few hours and for the dredge I added rotisserie chicken seasoning. It turned out really good. Thank you. This is my go-to fried chicken recipe from now on.

I really enjoyed this recipe and I’m not even a fan of chicken or fried foods! This recipe is easy, has an awesome foundation that will give great results every time, but it also leaves room for experimentation which I love. I added 1 tsp. Onion powder, 1 tsp. Garlic powder and 1 tsp. Chili powder to the flour mixture and my family really enjoyed it. It was crispy but also very juicy. I served this Fried Chicken with Red Beans and Rice and Corn on the Cobb. But any side would work with this dish. Thank you for submitting this recipe it’s going in my cookbook for sure! :) 

P.S. Chefs be sure to watch your chicken carefully as it fries so not to burn it.

Tender, crispy and delicious is the way I would describe this great recipe. I used chicken tenders that I had on hand in an attempt to satisfy my daughter’s KFC craving and it worked! Thanks for the recipe and valuable cooking tips!
Very good. Even better so "brine" the chicken in the buttermilk and seasonings the night before. Then do everything as listed. Thanks for posting a winning recipe!
Recipe was delicious! Chicken was great hot or cold.

DEFINITELY 5 STARS! My husband went turkey hunting yesterday and I was looking for a good recipe to use with the wild turkey breast meat. This worked out perfectly. I sliced the turkey breasts into nuggets and marinated them in seasoned buttermilk for a couple of hours and then tossed the nuggets in my seasoned flour in a ziplock bag. Followed instructions until I achieved the paste consistency and then fried them up in a cast iron pot. Since they were smaller nuggets, total cook time was less than 5 minutes. Will definitely be making these nuggets again. So good!!!

Very good! Had to make my own buttermilk, since I didn't have any in the house (I kept an article from previous email from all recipes).
I would definitely add more spices to this recipe.
Side note: I used boneless skinless thighs, (1) because that's what I had & (2) didn't have thermometer to gauge the oil temp...I cooked until deep golden brown(about 20-25 min).
Moist and absolutely crispy!!
A definite keeper
The chicken was as crispy on the outside as the description said. The meat was moist and tender. We used a deep fryer, but the chicken didn't use much oil. Yay! It wasn't greasy

I have never made fried chicken before; I remember my grandma's, which was delicious, but I rarely fry things. My 84 year old dad did not have a terrific appetite and I asked what would taste good...he said fried chicken. I added about a tablespoon of garlic powder and onion powder, and increased the paprika a bit, but followed the prep directions exactly. 
My dad just called and said it was the best chicken he has ever had *in his life*. 
Thanks Elaine!
The chicken was crispy but lacked seasoning; maybe if the recipe had garlic powder and onion powder it would of been better..I was disappointed.
This is the best fried chicken I’ve ever made

I read all of the reviews for knowledge, but honestly a lot of you are over thinking this. I put whatever seasonings. But the gist is the buttermilk, & flour resting. Used my electric presto with thermostat. Did wonderfully. I mean, use common sense to adjust seasoning & spices. Threw a turkey leg in the middle. Fab. Electric: Started at 375 until a bead of water danced. Turn, Turn after a light brown, I watched at this point! Then I changed dial to 300* & put lid on for 10 min/flipped-reset timer/flipped to = 30 min. Cranked to 375 & quickly flipped. Than tree in last two drumsticks on 350* & watched

The method seemed fine, and I put on my own spices into the flour mix to get the flavor that I wanted. My biggest problem with this recipe is that there's no specificity or even ballpark figures. She says that the oil needs to get hot, but how hot? Should be bubbling? Should it be smoking? And then when she says to put the chicken in the flour and then let it rest until the flower gets to a paste-like consistency, how long should that take? Approximately how long should that take? I know that it probably can change depending upon how much flour you put on it, if you double battered it, or other factors, but for someone who's trying this recipe for the very first time, are we talking about something that should take 5 minutes, or 2 hours? I have no idea, and I felt that the recipe was riddled with non specific things that assume you're already a fried chicken expert before you try this recipe.

Ive been cooking for 45 yrs and this is the best fried chicken recipe ever! I did add garlic powder and didnr have buttermilk so i soured some milk with vinegar...the secret is to let the coating sit until pasty...yummm!

Ok so this technique worked perfectly (with some changes mostly because I was using boneless skinless chicken breast). I had been using another recipe that was far more complicated (involving triple dipping) but the problem with it was that the coating, while delicious, wasn't sticking to the chicken! Kind of a problem. My chicken breast recipe calls for the chicken to be marinated overnight in the buttermilk, and spices, so this was PERFECT. I pulled it out of the bag that it was marinating in, dipped it in the flour/seasoning bag (I only seasoned a bit because there's quite a bit of seasoning in my marinade) and WAITED for the paste like consistency. It took about an hour and 25 minutes just fyi. We then cooked it at 350 (the whole time because it wasn't whole pieces) for about 6 to 7 minutes I want to say (until it was crispy and brown) and it was PERFECT. And the coating STUCK!!!! And it was easier. So thank you!!
OMG! OLD TIME CRISPY, TASTY FIED CHICKEN THAT WAS DELICIOUS HOT OR COLD. MY HUSBAND MADE THIS WITH NO TROUBLE. TRY IT!
My family really liked the chicken fixed . It was nice and crispy and moist,I will make it again
very crispy, buttermilk works good!
I added seasoning to everything, the brine, the flour, the wash, it all got more seasoning! It turned out great! Nice and moist. Good crispy skin. I’ll make this again!
You make great chicken, and no one makes better chicken than you.

Fixed chicken legs in my first cast iron skillet. I didn't have paprika so I used tumeric, and make my own buttermilk with vinegar added to whole milk. Turned out great--but the direction to "turn down heat, cover and cook 30 minutes"
wasn't clear enough for me to know how much to turn down.

This is the first one I’ve tried, so maybe I’m underrating it at 4 stars, but I’d say it’s a good sign that I’m comparing it to fast food chicken. The crispyness of the fried chicken needs some flavoring but overall the chicken was very good. I’m going to tinker with the seasoning to make the skin more flavorful
This was an ez win on super bowl Sunday

My family loved this! The breading didn't fall off like every other time I've tried frying anything. I did flip the chicken and check the internal temp of the chicken during the 30 mins. I didn't need to cook it for the full 30 mins. The chicken ended up crispy on the outside and juicy. Will make again!
The taste was bland, I would recommend adding seasoning with flavor before dipping the chicken in buttermilk

I have finally made a fried chicken that my husband would eat! I basically did everything described. I used smoked paprika and garlic pepper with he salt. I didn’t let the chicken sit long enough to get gooey. I will be sure I do that next time. I used the kernel of popcorn method to get my oil hot enough to brown the chicken. I then reduced the heat to medium low and covered my cast iron. I set a timer for 30 minutes and waited it kind of close. After 30 minutes, I removed the lid, increased the heat to just above medium (electric stove) and it took 10-15 minutes for the chicken to crisp. I turned halfway through the cooking time for browning and crisping. Our chicken looked like grandma’s fried chicken and had good flavor. We like plain spices, so I didn’t add hot pepper flakes or anything like that. I filled my cast iron skillet (with high sides) about 1/3 full. I hope my review is helpful to inexperienced cooks.
One of my boyz favorite meal. They requested it on a weekly basis. I marinate it overnight in hot sauce and other seasonings. You have to double coat like the instructions say to come out perfectly.
This was amazing I ate the whole thing by myself. I made it for my wife and then she got mad and left me for my brother. So single I am.

Chicken is perfect!! Oil temp should be 375. It will cool down once the chicken is in, then keep around 325 while frying. I love fried chicken with hot spices, but my grandkids don’t appreciate spicy foods, so I think the minimal seasonings in this are perfect. I added turmeric. Will be making again.
This is my go to chicken recipe from now on. Your technic is awesome. Followed the instructions to a tee. Sorry no pic, cause we ate it fast!

I made this using chicken breasts cut into strips. I added a touch of garlic powder, otherwise exactly as written. Cooked it maybe 15 mins. It got rave reviews from all my kids. And my husband, who is stingy with compliments even said how delicious it was. I’ll definitely make this again!
Really good
This was the first time making fried chicken, and this recipe delivered! Recipe was easy to follow, produced chicken that was juicy and crispy. Will definitely make again.
I made this tonight an I am sad to say that I won't make it again. The breading had no flavor.
Stuck to the recipe. Delicious!!

My mommy made THE BEST chicken (like ALL mommys do!) And I've been frying chicken forever, sometimes in buttermilk or Ranch, even 1000 Island on zingy flavor nights.. but i just KNEW there was something i was missing. Let the Chicken coating become a paste!!! Thank you! When i read that i remembered how mommy would put the chicken in the fridge, i had just forgot why.. xoxo to you for the "secret" that i forgot!
I made this chicken for my kids last night and they loved it! Had some leftover so that'll be my lunch today! Thanks!
Finally!!!!!! Thank you! Just add your own spice preference. Perfection!

This recipe was great. I followed it closely including letting the battered chicken set for over an hour. Was generous with salt, pepper, and paprika, putting it on chicken before the buttermilk wash as well as in the flour mixture. The family loved it! We will make this again.

First time making fried chicken here.. roughly used Food Network's recipe, but followed this technique, since reviews said the recipe was bland. And i believe it, bc the recipe i used was a tad step up but i wasn't excited about the flavor, and it's a bit too salty. I had 5 chicken legs (not quite 2#) brined overnight, rinsed and let it drain and warm with ambient temperature. I substitute buttermilk, 1/8C almond milk to 3/8C to make 1/2C "buttermilk" substitute; for the mix i used: 1.5C flour, 1T salt (plan to cut to 2tsp next time!), 1T black pepper, 1/2T garlic, 1/4T onion, 1/2tsp paprika, 1/2tsp red(cayenne) pepper; I used my carbon steel wok and had it filled with just enough oil to submerge half the chicken. Fried the first side for 15min before flipping to other side for 10min to try to mitigate overfrying. I ended up overfrying and inside was maybe just a smidge undercooked? just nuked in microwave for 1min to be on safer side. I did not do the cook through with lid cover...so will do that next time (I was afraid of losing crispiness after already overfried the outside)! Still had at least half of the flour-mixture remain - so it's a good amount.
I browned in the deep fryer then put in a frying pan and covered and simmered for 1/2 hour. Put it in a large baking pan warmed at dinner time in a hot oven . Very good and will definitely make again

So disappointed I love fried chicken but stay away from the frying, so gave it a try anyway, the technique was good but no taste at all, OK no raw chicken but no flavor to this, and took so long to make. made only two whole legs and of course way tooooo much flour, but will have to play with the spices. thank you anyway. I love Allrecipes
Delicious!

Absolutely fabulous fried chicken! Did add a few additional spices, 1/2 tsp of poultry seasoning, garlic powder, onion powder and Emeril’s and used House Autry Chicken Breader in place of the flower. Fry as directed, then place on absorbent paper. Drained the oil through a strainer and retained the extra crispy‘s back into the pan adding 1/4 cup of the breading mix with 3 tbsp of the oil on high heat stir until smooth then add 2 cups milk adding salt and pepper to taste, stirring constantly heat until a rich creamy consistency, serve over mashed potatoes!

Definitely love this technique! Didn’t have any buttermilk so I just used eggs instead, but next time I will get buttermilk. I love the technique of letting the chicken sit once floured, you can definitely see and taste a difference! Husband and son loved it! Great recipe!!

Made this for dinner a few nights ago. Followed the recipe except for the addition of some hot sauce mixed in with the buttermilk. Chicken came out moist and juicy on the inside and crisp and crunchy on the outside. Hubs especially liked it. Will definitely be making this again.

I'm rating 5 stars because I KNOW this is a great recipe. But it didn't turn out as good as I hoped (there was still none left, mind you). I'm going to do it again now that I know the following:

1. After reading MANY reviews I finally found one reviewer (AFTER I cooked it) who revealed the flour can take 30 minutes to reach that "pasty" consistency, which is critical to this working. The recipe doesn't give you an idea how long it takes, so if you've never done it you really don't know how long you should expect it to take. That may explain people jumping the gun on this step (like I did).

2. I think real Buttermilk (not a substitute like I used) is a critical component to getting that paste. I could be wrong here but I'll use the real stuff next time.

3. Mine was a little bland, like many others. But I think that's because if you're someone who likes to taste a lot of seasoning it takes a lot more than the recipe calls for to cut through 2 cups of flour. I could taste it a little but I'll add quite a bit more next time.

4. I used one of these counter-top electric fryer-type things, so I was able to dial in the temp to 375. But my chicken got more brown than I wanted it to, and it got there pretty quickly. Even without fully reaching the pasty phase though, I could tell the skin was definitely different.

Next time I'll either cook it at a lower temp or omit the Paprika, since it's a browning agent.

Other things were a little unclear because the instructions differe

I never knew how to make fried chicken so I never made it. I made this recipe and I am a believer. This recipe is remarkable. 
Thank you, Elaine O for sharing !!
This is my new Sunday nite dinner.

I made this yesterday and I couldn't agree more with the comments. This recipe works because of the technique**.
The choice of seasoning and quantities is up to you! But do make sure that after you dip (or marinate) in buttermilk you toss the chicken in a bag with the flour mixture (in batches) and let it sit**** for at least 30 minutes!!!. Also I did follow instructions and covered the chicken while it was sitting in the flour mixture, I think this helps keep the coating wet. I used my cold oven to house the cookie sheets with the covered chicken. 20 min after I started heating up the oil in a cast iron dutch oven and by the time 30-35min passed the oil was hot and ready. The chicken is going to have a sticky paste coating when ready. One more thing, make sure your oil is hot and stays hot. Between 350*F to 375*F. I made chicken wings and boneless strips so I didn't have to cover and let cook for 30 min. 10-12 min is all my chicken needed. I gave the recipe 4 stars because it's pretty vague so you need to have some cooking experience to get a successful batch but the technique is the key**

Delicious! I'm an amateur cook so I found this recipe so simple yet heavenly. The crispiness was perfect and the texture was amazing. The only problem was that it wasn't very flavorful but I fixed that problem by frying the chicken in coconut oil (instead of vegetable oil) with a pinch of chili oil. Apart from that, my family and I loved it! Will definitely cook again!

Elaine O Ty so much for this recipe. Fried chicken was something I made one time and it was ok for a first timer. BUT this made me a pro! I heavily seasoned the flour with Lawry's seasoned salt. Followed your instructions and it was better than Popeye's. It did take hours tho. That's the ONLY bad thing. This was some bangin chicken.
Best fried chicken I’ve ever made hands down.

This recipe turned out pretty good. It would have helped if the amount of salt and pepper were listed rather than. Season to taste made me a little skittish about adding to much salt. I will use this in the future with a few additions such as some brown sugar and more salt.

I made this exactly as written. The chicken stayed juicy and tasted delicious. The coating browned up nicely and was crispy. However, it lacked flavor. I'm probably used to restaurant fried chicken, and maybe theirs is nothing like the real deal - I don't know. But this tasted like a crunchy coating of flour on my chicken. There was zero flavor. For the time and effort involved, it wasn't worth mine.
I have made fried chicken with this recipe twice now and both times it has turned out wonderful. I will be using the recipe from now on!
I just added some garlic powder and onion powder as others did. I made my own buttermilk. They were so crispy and so good.

Delicious! I deviated a little from the original recipe but not the advice to let the flowered chicken sit covered until it becomes a little pasty. This takes about a half hour. The recipe said to lower the heat, and cook for 30 minutes, then increase the heat again. I kept cooking the chicken at relatively high heat, just lowered slightly, and turned frequently. It turned out great.

I made this without brining the chicken on the first attempt and it was even better the next day cold. I am trying it this time and brining the chicken in kosher salt water with brown sugar , soy sauce, and olive oil. The chicken is much more moist and it didn't take nearly as long for it to turn the coating into a paste.

Put in about 1 tsp of Adobo seasoning instead of salt and pepper. Very fussy about oil, so used peanut oil to fry. Very nice. Perfectly cooked, crispy, moist. I have no deep fryer, nor an appropriate thermometer. Put my gas "power burner" on at high for the browning, low for the slow cooking.
Comes out perfect every time!

you real deserved many thank 
thank alot

This was the perfect recipe for a novice like me, very easy to follow. I used seasoned salt instead of just adding the paprika on its own and loved the taste. Was too impatient to let the battered chicken sit and get that paste-like consistency as was suggested before frying lol, but I'll do it right next time and it still tasted great when I made it the first time regardless!
Made exactly as directed. Easy, moist, & crunchy crispy delicious. 1 change when I make this next time will be to season the flour and/or chicken as it was a little bland.

When my Mother made fried chicken I remember she coated the chicken with the flour mixture and put it in a skillet of hot oil to fry it. In this recipe they want you to brown it in the hot oil then cook for an additional 30 which I found odd. When the oil got to be the right high temp I ended up cooking each side for five to six minutes and it came out great. In fact the skin was super crispy and crunchy. No additional 30 min needed on a low temp. Just saying.
I use exactly the same frying method with my chicken but adding the buttermilk is great
Absolutely fantastic and absolutely perfect.
the best
First time making fried chicken. My family loved it. It was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. Can't wait to make it again.
So easy to make. Turned out very crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. I made this as written, I will experiment with more spices next time for even more flavor.
Tasty and crispy! I used to use a great Ina Garten recipe each time I made fried chicken, but since I discovered this one, I've used it the past 3 or 4 times. Yummy!

very delicious recipe.
http://smartkitchenpicks.com
This recipe didn't wow me. It was dry and not so flaky or bubbly as crispy chicken i eat in restaurants. Won't make again.
I have struggled with fried chicken over the years, but I succeeded with this recipe. I added some seasoned salt to the flour mixture. Followed the method to a T and am very happy with the results.
I make this chicken often for my family and friends. Every time I get rave reviews. It is SO juicy in the middle and crispy on the outside. Best, most simple fried chicken recipe out there!
I didn't have buttermilk because I had used it all to make hidden valley ranch...so I used the Hidden valley ranch...it was the best fried chicken I have ever made !

This turned out great. Perfect crunch, but next time I'll add more salt to the flour mix. I used my cast iron skillet, a thermometer to monitor oil heat and checked the chicken temp, removing at 160 degrees. I had a small issue keeping the oil temp at 375, but once I got it to stay there, the chicken fried perfectly. I fried in batches and kept the other chicken warm in a 250 degree oven. New and experienced cooks can learn from the video. I don't fry foods too often, so it was a real help.
